title: How many buttons are on a computer keyboard? - Quora

response.answer_text: As per Computer keyboard - Wikipedia: Desktop computer keyboards, such as the 101-key US traditional keyboards or the 104-key Windows keyboards, include alphabetic characters, punctuation symbols, numbers and a variety of function keys. The internationally common 102/104 key keyboards have a smaller left shift key and an additional key with some more symbols between that and the letter to its right (usually Z or Y). Also the enter key is usually shaped differently. Computer keyboards are similar to electric-typewriter keyboards but contain additional keys, such as the command or Windows keys. There is no standard computer keyboard, although many manufacturers imitate the keyboard of PCs. There are actually three different PC keyboards: the original PC keyboard with 84 keys, the AT keyboard also with 84 keys and the enhanced keyboard with 101 keys. The three differ somewhat in the placement of function keys, the control keys, the return key, and the shift key. There are also Keyboard Shortcuts created for efficiency purposes. Keyboard shortcut keys vary depending on what Operating System you are using. Windows OS, Mac OS, Linux and Unix all have different keys used when typing the shortcuts. Windows OS Keyboard Shortcut Keys (with Special Characters) Keyboard shortcut keys for Windows Operating System consists of 36 shortcuts for the basic and 22 shortcuts for special characters. The table below shows you the complete list of the Basic Keyboard Shortcut Keys for Windows Operating System:  For more information, you can check it here: All The Keyboard Shortcuts You Can Use For a typing program that can help you learn how to master the keys in a keyboard and touch type properly, I suggest checking Typesy.

The number of keys on a keyboard depends on the size of the keyboard… There are many different sizes of keyboards available nowadays Full-Size keyboard  These keyboards have 104, 105 or 108 keys and include a dedicated number pad as well. Tenkeyless Keyboard  These keyboards have 87 or 88 keys and lack a dedicated number pad. 75% Keyboards  These keyboards have almost the same number of keys as of the Tenkeyless keyboard but is a little shrunk. 60% Keyboard  These keyboards lack a function row as well as the arrow keys and some other keys and are even smaller than 75% Keyboards. These are some of the most commonly used keyboard layouts although there are even smaller keyboards and you rarely see them. Hope it helps Source:Full-size, TKL, 60% and more: a guide to mechanical keyboard sizes
